title: How to get big money for your big idea by an investor who knows
text:
Coffee entrepreneur Ashley Lopez offers a glimpse past the glass ceiling for many entrepreneurs, even though female-founded companies continue to receive less than one per cent of the UK's total venture capital.

The American expat took the reins of a conceptualized coffee shop – the Department of Coffee and Social Affairs – in her early twenties and whipped the idea into a successful specialty coffee conglomerate within a decade.

These days, the 32-year-old's 'Coffeesmiths Collective' now employs over 1,000 staff in the UK and US, leaving Lopez with the time (and money) to transition from investee to investor.

By her own admission, little of her fortune was particularly well-planned; after completing her Masters in Law & Finance at Queen Mary University in 2010, she had no clear goal in mind – just that she wanted to stay in the UK while she figured it out.

With a post-grad visa in tow, she decided to continue her adult education working in the private office of investors Stefan Allesch-Taylor and Matthew Gill.

It was here that the Department of Coffee and Social Affairs created a fork in her road. “Some guys brought the idea to Stefan and Matt when they were looking to diversify and try new investments,” Lopez recalls. “They asked me to go in as one of the founding partners and get it off the ground."
